data.title: The Most Spectacular Concert Venues in the World
data.meta_description: Making Culture Pop. Find the latest entertainment news and the best in music, pop culture, sneakers, style and original shows.
data.text:
By Michelle Geslani

When it comes to live shows, the venue plays an integral part in one's concert-going experience. A musical act's performance is reliant on almost everything that venue provides, from the ambiance to the sound system, yet these amphitheaters and concert halls often go unappreciated. To give credit where credit is due, here are some of the world's most stunning, most spectacular concert venues. Time to update that bucket list of yours, because these places are definitely worth visiting. Check out the 25 most spectacular concert venues in the world.

1.Princes Street Garden

Location: Edinburgh, Scotland

Year opened: ~1820s

Genres: classical, rock, pop

The Princes Street Gardens is a public park in the center of Edinburgh, located below the stately Edinburgh Castle that sits high above on Castle Rock. It was created in the 1820s following the draining of the Nor Loch—a large, polluted loch originally built as a means of defense—and the construction of the city's "New Town" section. Altogether, it covers over nearly 40 acres of land and is full of lovely flora, monuments, and benches for tourists and locals alike. In addition to hosting concerts at its Ross Theatre Bandstand, the Gardens also holds special festivities during the annual Hogmanay celebrations (Scottish version of New Years).

2.Greek Theater

Location: Berkeley, CA

Year opened: 1903

Genres: pop, rock, jazz

Though it's located by the Bay, The William Randolph Hearst Greek Theatre, or Greek Theatre as it's better known, is an exquisite outdoor amphitheater that transports visitors back to ancient Greece. Its formal name comes from its financier, newspaper baron William Randolph Hearst, and its design is inspired by the actual Greek theater at Epidaurus. Its fully operated by the University of California, Berkeley (built to be the "Athens of the West") and, in addition to graduation ceremonies, hosts a number of jazz, pop, and rock concerts throughout the year.

3.Dalhalla

Location: Rattvik, Sweden

Year opened: 1993

Genres: jazz, classical, opera, rock, pop

If you're looking to escape the concrete jungle, look no further than central Sweden's Dalhalla. Surrounded by forests, this amazing amphitheater is located in a former limestone quarry and even has its very own "moat" that separates the stage from the audience. Even though it's only open during the summer months, Dalhalla presents about 20-30 events and easily attracts more than 100,000 visitors to its tranquil setting. It's magical and mesmerizing, making its name so appropriate—Dalhalla is a reference to "Valhalla," which, according to Scandinavian mythology, is a "hall in which heroes killed in battle were believed to feast with the god Odin for eternity."

4.The Gorge

Location: George, Washington

Year opened: 1985

Genres: rock, pop

The powers of music and nature meet here at Washington's Gorge Amphitheatre. Located about 150 miles east of Seattle, this 20,000-capacity property is impressive at every turn, from the acts and festivals it books (Pearl Jam, Sasquatch! Music Festival) to its gorgeous and inspiring views of the Columbia River and the Columbia Gorge Canyon. After seeing their favorite band perform on Mother Nature's grandiose stage, visitors can also extend the festivities by spending the night under a blanket of stars at the Gorge's adjacent campground. Sounds like a perfect day for any fan.

5.Slane Castle

Location: County Meath, Ireland

Year opened: 1701

Genres: rock, pop, opera

You don't have to be royalty to attend a concert at Ireland's famed Slane Castle, though after a day spent on the grounds you just might feel like it. Built over three centuries ago by the Conyngham family, the grand Gothic-style castle faces a natural amphitheater formed by the surrounding sloping grounds and overlooks the nearby River Boyne. Located about 40 miles north of Dublin, the impressive structure—with its beautiful stained glass windows and many magnificent rooms—has been known to host weddings and other special events. Since 1981, the entire 80,000-capacity property has held large-scale concerts, including performances by David Bowie, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Madonna, and Bruce Springsteen.

6.Palais Garnier

Location: Paris, France

Year opened: 1875

Genres: opera, classical

Much like Notre Dame Cathedral or the Louvre, Palais Garnier has become a worldwide symbol of Paris. Its name might not be very familiar, but its interior should jog your memory: this Charles Garnier-designed venue was used as the setting for Gaston Leroux's 1910 classic novel The Phantom of the Opera, as well as Andrew Lloyd Webber's subsequent musical adaptation. And it's hard not to see why it was chosen, considering its total commitment to opulence—a gorgeous marble staircase, awe-inspiring grand foyer, and six-ton radiant chandelier are just a few of its extravagant touches.

7.Teatro alla Scala (La Scala)

Location: Milan, Italy

Year opened: 1778

Genres: classical, ballet, opera

Looking up into the vast expanse of Milan's La Scala will simply take your breath away. Even though it's over 200 years old, this world-renowned space still retains much of its original sophistication and grandeur in each of its six towering tiers and 2800 seats. (It's also changed to keep up with the times: most of the seats come with built-in monitors to help with translations during certain events.) Not surprisingly, patrons here have high standards for La Scala's presentations—crowds have been known to outright jeer and heckle subpar performers. In addition to a theatre space, the structure also houses a museum full of paintings and costumes and an academy that helps foster young musicians.

8.Sarawak Cultural Village

Location: Kuching, Borneo (Malaysia)

Year opened: 1990

Genres: world music

Built to both showcase and preserve the life and culture of Borneo's local tribes, Sarawak Cultural Village is an award-winning "living museum" and the location of the Rainforest World Music Festival, a world renowned three-day event that draws as many as 24,000 people. Visitors can experience local life firsthand, learning about various tribes' customs, dances, and music, with the backdrop of actual rain-forests, farm houses, long houses, and the legendary Santubong Mountain as added scenic bonuses. Whether you're a festival attendee or simply hungry for history, the village is an enriching and exotic adventure.

9.Great American Music Hall

Location: San Francisco, CA

Year opened: 1907

Genres: pop, rock

The Bay Area's Great American Music Hall has undergone a number of incarnations over the last century. Once a poppin' jazz space and even a late-night burlesque dancing spot, Today, it's known as one of the most ornate medium-sized clubs to showcase both new and old acts. From the detailed balconies to the towering marble columns to the intricately fashioned ceiling frescoes, concertgoers are often stunned not only by the live music before them, but by the breathtaking decor all around.

10.Teatro Colon

Location: Buenos Aires, Argentina

Year opened: 1908

Genres: classical, opera

Replacing an original theater which opened in 1857, the current Italian/French style Teatro Colon is the main opera house in all of Buenos Aires. Though it endured a lengthy and frustrating 18-year building process—mired by death and murder—it was all worth it in the end: this exquisite venue is said to have one of the best acoustics in all the world, its near perfection even praised by the late and great Luciano Pavarotti, who said, "The acoustics are so good that every mistake can be heard." Acoustics aside, the decor itself will leave visitors at a loss for words—three kinds of Italian marble, French stained glass, a 700-light stately chandelier, and 2500 seats spread across seven stunning tiers all make the Teatro Colon a truly luxurious and inspiring space.

11.Bolshoi Theater

Location: Moscow, Russia

Year opened: 1825

Genres: ballet, opera

Because Russians deemed the opera and ballet the most noble of presentations, they housed them in the grandest of spaces, hence the name Bolshoi Theatre ("Big Theatre"). After weathering financial turmoil and political unrest, including the collapse of the Soviet Union, it's become a historic and cultural landmark not only of Moscow, but of the country as a whole, its majestic Neoclassical facade even depicted on the Russian 100-ruble banknote. The structure has fostered some of the oldest and most renown ballet and opera companies in the world and been the site of many significant premieres such as Tchaikovsky's legendary Swan Lake ballet in 1877.

12.Koncerthuset

Location: Copenhagen, Denmark

Year opened: 2009

Genres: classical, jazz, pop, rock

From the outside, Copenhagen's Koncerthuset immediately takes your breath away: a giant, glowing blue cube seemingly beamed down from another planet. It features a 6,000-pipe organ and big blue walls that not only serve as the building's outer shell, but can also be used as actual project screens. Likely the most expensive concert hall built to this day (an astonishing $300 million), the four-hall structure is home to the Danish National Symphony Orchestra and the Danish Broadcasting Corporation.

13.Red Rocks Amphitheatre

Location: Morrison, CO

Year opened: 1906

Genres: rock, pop, opera

A concert space that's literally carved into a mountainside, Red Rocks Amphitheatre is like nothing else in the world. From the breathtaking scenery of Red Rocks Park and beyond to the absolutely jaw-dropping views of the concert stage, Red Rocks is both a spectacular piece of nature and an entertainment wonderland. It has presented all kinds of acts, everything from folk to hip-hop, even hosting The Beatles back in 1964. But no matter the occasion or the event, any experience here will surely be a truly unforgettable one.

14.Mountain Winery

Location: Saratoga, CA

Year opened: 1901

Genres: rock, pop, classical, jazz

With Silicon Valley as its dramatic backdrop, Mountain Winery is quite the unique outdoor location for nearly any event—concert, conference, wedding—you name it. Wine-making ceased back in 1958 when the venue began to hold concerts, but has thankfully been brought back. Even though it's over 100 years old, it's aged gracefully and still retains much of its early history and old-world charm. Offering world class music, wine, and astounding views, it's no surprise that it's been listed as a California Historical Landmark and part of the National Register of Historical Places.

15.Théâtre Antique d’Orange

Location: Orange, France

Year opened: ~1st century AD

Genres: opera

The ancient theatre of Orange is literally that: one of the best preserved ancient Roman theaters, dating back to 40BC, originally in the Roman colony of Arausio in Southern France. The structure itself was constructed around the 1st century AD and originally served as a venue for all forms of entertainment for the locals, such as pantomime and poetry readings. Even though it ceased productions in 391 AD, it assumed other purposes, including refuge during wartimes and as a defensive station during the Middle Ages. It wasn't until the 19th century that it was finally restored and put to use again, ushering a new era of rebirth for the theatre. Today, it holds the lovely summer opera festival, ‪Chorégies d'Orange‬, as well as a number of other events.

16.The Royal Albert Hall

Location: London, UK

Year opened: 1871

Genres: classical, ballet, opera, rock, pop

A venue of rich grandeur and history, the Royal Albert Hall was first opened by Queen Victoria in 1871. Designed by Captain Frances Fowke and Major-General Henry Scott, it was originally inspired by the early amphitheaters of Greece and dedicated to the arts and sciences, both of which were beloved by the Queen's husband, Prince Albert. Today, it is one of the UK's most venerated and well-known structures, home to more than 350 events a year, including the annual summer Proms. Whether you're admiring its glowing ceiling orbs or its beautiful mosaic frieze, or maybe recognize it from a scene of the 1934 film, The Man Who Knew Too Much, you're bound to be in awe of this truly royal space.

17.The National Centre for Performing Arts

Location: Beijing, China

Year opened: 2007

Genres: classical, ballet, theatre

Located near Tiananmen Square and the Forbidden City, the National Centre for Performing Arts is unlike any other structure in the world. Locals have dubbed it "The Giant Egg", but many patrons of this half titanium, half glass futuristic beauty are often left speechless. The venue's dramatics are further enhanced by the surrounding manmade 35,500 square meter lake, which offers stunning crystalline reflections, especially at night.

18.The Royal Opera House Muscat

Location: Muscat, Oman

Year opened: 2011

Genres: classical, ballet, theatre

The relatively new Royal Opera House is the premier location for music, arts, and culture in all of Oman, a country that borders Yemen and sits on the Arabian Sea. Built on the orders of Oman's classical-music-loving Sultan Qaboos by Wimberly Allison Tong and Goo, it reflects contemporary Omani architecture as well as traditional Arabic designs. A true product of its time, the venue is the first in the world to use Radio Marconi's MODE 23, a multimedia interactive system built right into each of the venue's 1,100 seats. It also makes use of advanced automated stage engineering, meaning that it can amazingly transform its space to accommodate any event.

19.Auditorio de Tenerife "Adan Martin"

Location: Santa Cruz, Canary Islands (Spain)

Year opened: 2003

Genres: classical, rock, pop

Even before you set your eyes on its stage, the Auditorio de Tenerife already has your attention with its unique, almost gravity-defying shape. Named in honor of the former President of the Canary Islands, Adan Martin, this structure, with its use of Spanish architecture both new and old, has become the symbol of the city of Santa Cruz. (Its picture has even been featured on commemorative coins and stamps.) Inside, organ pipes emerge from both sides of the pit and audience members are literally surrounded by walls of sound. Outside, the building is occasionally lit up in various colors during the evening hours; from afar looking like a mysterious sea creature.

20.Radio City Music Hall

Location: New York, NY

Year opened: 1932

Genres: classical, pop, rock, hip-hop

Located within New York City's famed Rockefeller Center, Radio City Music Hall is one of the world's most well-known venues. Commissioned by American industrialist and philanthropist John D. Rockefeller and designed in an Art Deco style by Edward Durell Stone and Donald Deskey, the building gets its name from one of its first tenants, the Radio Corporation of America (RCA). Even though the auditorium's enormous space can seat more than 5,000 people, its brilliant radiating arches not only serve to inspire and induce jaw-dropping stares, but also foster a surprisingly warm and intimate feel.

21.Harpa Concert Hall

Location: Reykjavik, Iceland

Year opened: 2011

Genres: classical, pop, rock

An artistic sight in of itself, this modern concert hall and conference center was designed by Danish firm Henninh Larsen Architects and Danish-Icelandic artist Olafur Eliasson, known for his work on the 2008 New York City Waterfalls installation project. Built on a steel framework and covered in geometric-shaped pieces of colored glass, Harpa's natural but ever-changing glow is said to be influenced by Iceland's dynamic and beautiful landscapes of volcanoes, lava fields, mountains, geysers, and glaciers. In addition to individual large-scale meetings and events, the venue also partakes in the country's big annual music festival, Iceland Airwaves.

22.Konzerthaus

Location: Berlin, Germany

Year opened: 1821

Genres: classical, opera, pop, rock

Designed by Karl Friedrich Schinkel, the foundations of Berlin's Konzerthaus date back to the early 19th century. It's undergone a number of name changes and uses since then—it was once called Schauspielhaus and its main auditorium once housed the Prussian National Assembly—but has since become the home of the German orchestra Konzerthausorhchester Berlin. From its interior filled with magnificent chandeliers to its outside sculptures of composers to its impressive 5,811-pipe organ, it's a storied and grand masterpiece.

23.Wiener Musikverein

Location: Vienna, Austria

Year opened: 1870

Genres: classical

Beautifully ornate from top to bottom, the Wiener Musikverein "(Viennese Music Association") is truly a breathtaking sight to behold. Built in the Neoclassical style of an ancient Greek Temple by Danish architect Theophil Hansen, it was created as the new concert hall of Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde ("Society of Friends of the Music in Vienna"). To this day, it remains the center of Viennese musical culture and the home of the city's philharmonic orchestra.

24.Concertgebouw

Location: Amsterdam, Netherlands

Year opened: 1888

Genres: classical, opera, jazz, rock, world music

With its seats draped in burgundy hues, it's hard not to see why visitors are quick to describe this venue as royal. Amsterdam's Concertgebouw (Dutch for "Concert Hall") was built by Adolf Leonard van Gendt and is known to have one of the best acoustics in the world. While it's the official home of the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra, the hall has hosted a wide range of musical acts, including Led Zeppelin and The Who during the 1960s, and presents nearly 900 events each year.

25.Starlight Theatre

Location: Kansas City, MO

Year opened: 1951

Genres: musicals, rock, pop

An arts and culture hotspot for Kansas City and its surrounding communities, the Starlight Theatre is one of the very few self-producing outdoor theaters in all of the United States. Located within the city's Swope Park, the venue is expansive, set under a sky of stars, yet still has the feeling of an intimate space, with most seats offering generous sight lines. Starlight not only presents concerts, but is fully equipped to handle even major Broadway musicals; in the past, it's welcomed Annie Get Your Gun, The King and I, and Les Miserables to its stage.
